description: From Late Latin clavicytherium, from Medieval Latin clāvis (“key”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *(s)kleh₂w- (“crook, hook, peg”), possibly through Ancient Greek κλείς (kleís, “bar, bolt; key”)) + cithara (“cithara, guitar, lute, lyre”) (from Ancient Greek κῐθᾰ́ρᾱ (kithárā, “lyre”)) + -ium (“suffix forming nouns”).

entries.meaning: (music) A harpsichord in which the soundboard and strings are mounted vertically facing the player. [early 16th c.]
